natural problem: If the function $j(x)$ is defined only on domain $[-1,2]$, and is defined on this domain by the formula $$j(x) = 2x^2+1,$$ then what is the range of $j(x)$? Express your answer as an interval or as a union of intervals.
natural solution: Note that $x^2$ assumes every value from $0$ to $4$, inclusive, as $x$ varies throughout the interval $[-1,2]$.
Therefore, $j(x)$ assumes every value from $2(0)+1=1$ to $2(4)+1=9$ (and no other values). The range of $j(x)$ is $\boxed{[1,9]}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes j :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (-1 \<le> x) \<and> (x \<le> 2) \<longrightarrow> j x = 2 * x powr 2 + 1"
shows  "range j = { y. 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 9 }"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 If the function $j(x)$ is defined only on domain $[-1,2]$, and is defined on this domain by the formula $$j(x) = 2x^2+1,$$ then what is the range of $j(x)$? Express your answer as an interval or as a union of intervals. The final Answer is [1,9]
 ### Proof
 Note that $x^2$ assumes every value from $0$ to $4$, inclusive, as $x$ varies throughout the interval $[-1,2]$.
 Therefore, $j(x)$ assumes every value from $2(0)+1=1$ to $2(4)+1=9$ (and no other values). The range of $j(x)$ is $\boxed{[1,9]}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes j :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (-1 \<le> x) \<and> (x \<le> 2) \<longrightarrow> j x = 2 * x powr 2 + 1"
shows  "range j = { y. 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 9 }"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For a function $j(x)$ defined as $j(x) = 2x^2 + 1$ for $-1 \leq x \leq 2$, determine the range of $j(x)$. The range of $j(x)$ is the set of all $y$ values such that $1 \leq y \leq 9$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes j :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<longrightarrow> j x = 2 * x powr 2 + 1"
and h1 : "is_interval (range (\<lambda>x. j x))"
shows  "range (\<lambda>x. j x) = {1..9}"

and h1 : "is_interval (range (\<lambda>x. j x))"

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x j :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. -1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<longrightarrow> j x = 2 * x powr 2 + 1"
shows  "{y. \<exists> x. -1 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 2 \<and> y = j x} = {y. 1 \<le> y \<and> y \<le> 9}"

 *)

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
